snippet: This sentence, buried in the middle of the article ''Cheerleading Changes as Boys Join Sidelines'' on May 2, says it all: ''At the schools where the cheerleaders were interviewed, the squad still only went out to cheer for major boys' sports.''   ...
lead_paragraph: This sentence, buried in the middle of the article ''Cheerleading Changes as Boys Join Sidelines'' on May 2, says it all: ''At the schools where the cheerleaders were interviewed, the squad still only went out to cheer for major boys' sports.'' No matter how many boys sign up, until cheerleading squads are equally assigned to girls' sports as well, cheerleading (and its still predominantly female members) will continue to be viewed as serving the traditionally dominant male athletic culture in these schools. JENNY GEER Larchmont

snippet: A VERY BRUNDAGE is a brave man of such lofty principles that he deems compromise or expediency a coward's cloak. No sooner had the millionaire ex-decathlon champion been elected president of the International Olympic Committee last July, the first...
lead_paragraph: A VERY BRUNDAGE is a brave man of such lofty principles that he deems compromise or expediency a coward's cloak. No sooner had the millionaire ex-decathlon champion been elected president of the International Olympic Committee last July, the first American ever so honored, than he flailed away with his usual vigor at the evils threatening the Olympic movement. He pointed one accusing finger at the curse of "gigantism."

headline.main: Sports of The Times; More Deadly Than the Male

snippet: HIS credentials to coach women's professional basketball were unassailable, though Van Chancellor admits his original intentions were not altogether pure.    It was during the mid-1960's when Chancellor, teaching math and coaching boys' basketball...
lead_paragraph: HIS credentials to coach women's professional basketball were unassailable, though Van Chancellor admits his original intentions were not altogether pure. It was during the mid-1960's when Chancellor, teaching math and coaching boys' basketball in Horn Lake, Miss., went to the principal one day and said he needed a study hall break. ''There weren't too many math teachers in Mississippi in those days,'' the coach of the Houston Comets drawled recently on the phone. ''They told me they also needed a coach for the girls' team. If I took it over, I'd be able to get out of two classes a day.''

snippet: IN basketball, the answer to Sigmund Freud's long-discussed question -- what do women want? -- is not very complicated. Just ask Stephanie Ready.    She wants, generally, what guys want: a good job, respect, the chance to succeed or fail on her me...
lead_paragraph: IN basketball, the answer to Sigmund Freud's long-discussed question -- what do women want? -- is not very complicated. Just ask Stephanie Ready. She wants, generally, what guys want: a good job, respect, the chance to succeed or fail on her merits, in a passion of her choosing, and with no glass rafters. She wants to win and, as a coach, to develop good players along the way.
abstract: Ira Berkow's Sports of The Times column on Stephanie Ready, who will become assistant coach of Greenville (SC) Groove in National Basketball Association's new eight-team developmental league; league will essentially be NBA minor league and successor to defunct Continental Basketball Association; Ready is first female coach ever of American men's professional team; photo (M)

snippet: To the Sports Editor:   William C. Rhoden describes how the male-dominated ethic of sports can lead to the treatment of women as objects and to the tolerance of serious offenses such as rape ("No Lesson May Come in Tyson Verdict," The Times, Feb. ...
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: William C. Rhoden describes how the male-dominated ethic of sports can lead to the treatment of women as objects and to the tolerance of serious offenses such as rape ("No Lesson May Come in Tyson Verdict," The Times, Feb. 12). While I welcome an article on this subject, I wonder why Rhoden chose to quote only men. Are we to infer that only men can be experts on male domination?

headline.main: Why Quote Only Men?

snippet: Research showing a lag in the academic performance of Division III athletes has caught the N.C.A.A.'s attention. A review of first-year academic records at 88 of the division's most selective universities by the College Sports Project showed that ...
lead_paragraph: Research showing a lag in the academic performance of Division III athletes has caught the N.C.A.A.'s attention. A review of first-year academic records at 88 of the division's most selective universities by the College Sports Project showed that male athletes on average had poorer grades than their counterparts in the overall student body. The gap was larger for recruited male athletes. In response, the N.C.A.A. is considering tracking graduation rates and other measures of academic performance. Until now, that task has been left up to individual universities in Division III.

abstract: Wave of coaches embroiled in child sexual abuse scandals is garnering a closer look at the link between coaching and molestation; experts say the sports environment has all the ingredients to facilitate misconduct: coaches have close relationships with children and unsupervised access to them, while holding a position of trust and authority that can often keep children from reporting abuses.

headline.seo: Culture of Sports Works Against Children, Especially Boys, Reporting Abuse

snippet: To the Sports Editor:    It is ironic that the erosion of Title IX's socially salubrious requirements of gender equity in college sports was initiated by a lawsuit filed by the college wrestling coaches' association. Considering America's curious ...
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: It is ironic that the erosion of Title IX's socially salubrious requirements of gender equity in college sports was initiated by a lawsuit filed by the college wrestling coaches' association. Considering America's curious fascination with female wrestling, as evidenced by the recent number of pop culture references to this sport, one would think that instead of ending male programs, colleges and universities would advance female wrestling as a revenue producer that would rival football and basketball.

snippet: To the Sports Editor:    Three cheers for the article on Billy Bean and the problem of homophobia in male team sports (''A Major League Player's Life of Isolation and Secret Fear,'' The Times, Sept. 6).    I have experience being openly gay in two...
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: Three cheers for the article on Billy Bean and the problem of homophobia in male team sports (''A Major League Player's Life of Isolation and Secret Fear,'' The Times, Sept. 6). I have experience being openly gay in two worlds with strong traditions of hyper-masculinity and homophobia: Wall Street and heavy metal rock music. I've encountered plenty of enemies, but also plenty of intense support. The myth that all masculine straight men are homophobic has to be exploded.
abstract: William Dunmyer letter lauds September 6 article on Billy Bean and problem of homophobia in male team sports; written transcript and audio discussion of September 9 New York Times forum is available on Times' Web site (S)

headline.main: Debunking a Myth Of Homophobia

snippet: BRIAN BOITANO, widely recognized as the best male figure skater, yesterday called an article linking his sport with AIDS "ridiculous" and "a joke."   The Calgary Herald reported last weekend that 40 male skaters and coaches have died of AIDS in No...
lead_paragraph: BRIAN BOITANO, widely recognized as the best male figure skater, yesterday called an article linking his sport with AIDS "ridiculous" and "a joke." The Calgary Herald reported last weekend that 40 male skaters and coaches have died of AIDS in North America in recent years and that at least a dozen prominent American and Canadian male skaters have H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

headline.main: Boitano Speaks Out

abstract: ABC, among four big broadcasters, has completed fall ratings season with no help from the National Football League and virtually no help from sports programming at all; television viewing is dominated by women and about 62 percent of ABC audience is female; top five most popular shows among women are on ABC, as well as seven of 10 most popular.

snippet: LEAD: The top two seeded male players for the French Open, which starts May 28, are Stefan Edberg of Sweden, the loser in last year's final, and Boris Becker of West Germany. Ivan Lendl, a three-time French Open champion and the No. 1-ranked male ...
lead_paragraph: LEAD: The top two seeded male players for the French Open, which starts May 28, are Stefan Edberg of Sweden, the loser in last year's final, and Boris Becker of West Germany. Ivan Lendl, a three-time French Open champion and the No. 1-ranked male player in the world, is skipping the tournament to prepare for Wimbledon.

headline.main: Edberg Seeded No. 1

snippet: To the Sports Editor:    On every sports page there are tales of great athletes and the lengths taken for those athletes to achieve their goals. The majority of these pages are filled with male athletes and although there are women represented, it...
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: On every sports page there are tales of great athletes and the lengths taken for those athletes to achieve their goals. The majority of these pages are filled with male athletes and although there are women represented, it is not with the vigor that the men receive. Women also do great things, most recently the bobsled team that won Olympic gold, but do not receive as much attention. Female athletes should receive equal representation for their efforts. RACHEL A. JOHNSON Mesa, Ariz.
abstract: Letter to editor argues that female athletes, for example US Olympic female bobsled team, receive less attention and coverage from media than male athletes (M)

headline.main: Women Deserve Better

snippet: To the Sports Editor:  Teresa H. Skehan (Mailbox, Aug. 24) would like to see the use of a gender correct ''woman to woman'' to describe basketball in the Women's National Basketball Association, using such ''power gently and persistently toward a ...
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: Teresa H. Skehan (Mailbox, Aug. 24) would like to see the use of a gender correct ''woman to woman'' to describe basketball in the Women's National Basketball Association, using such ''power gently and persistently toward a more equal society.'' How absurd! Simply adopt a genderless phrase, the way the National Football League male sports announcers have done for years, more accurately describing a man-to-man defense for what it is -- one to one. GRADY THURMAN St. Croix, U.S. Virgin Islands
abstract: Grady Thurman letter comments on Teresa H Skehan's Aug 24 letter calling for 'gender correct' descriptions of play in Women's National Basketball Assn

headline.main: A Vote for 'One'

snippet: To the Sports Editor:    ''Another Male Coach Hired in W.N.B.A.'' (The Times, Dec. 8) was less a serious sports commentary than a piece of feel-good drivel. I presume the W.N.B.A.'s goal is not to be the type of quota-driven social laboratory that...
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: ''Another Male Coach Hired in W.N.B.A.'' (The Times, Dec. 8) was less a serious sports commentary than a piece of feel-good drivel. I presume the W.N.B.A.'s goal is not to be the type of quota-driven social laboratory that Harvey Araton seemingly desires, but to become profitable by offering the best quality entertainment possible. If the W.N.B.A. and its teams can do this by having all, none or some male coaches, I presume they will take the most advantageous course.
abstract: Edward S Hochman letter on Harvey Araton's Dec 8 article on concern over number of men being hired to coach teams in Women's National Basketball Association says Dec 8 article was less a serious sports commentary than piece of feel-good drivel (S)

snippet: To the Sports Editor:    Regarding ''Hoops, Hurt and Hoopla'' (The Times, Aug. 17): why did The Times think it was appropriate to include a photo of the Liberty forward Kym Hampton in the restroom doing her hair? According to the caption, Hampton ...
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: Regarding ''Hoops, Hurt and Hoopla'' (The Times, Aug. 17): why did The Times think it was appropriate to include a photo of the Liberty forward Kym Hampton in the restroom doing her hair? According to the caption, Hampton was preparing for a game. Did she not stretch, take practice shots and warm up in any way that would have provided you with a proper photo of a male athlete published in the sports section, and I am a longtime reader. Personal grooming does not seem to qualify as sports news. KAREN KOFFLER Kew Gardens, Queens
abstract: Karen Koffler letter questions why New York Times published photo of Liberty forward Kym Hampton doing her hair, with caption saying she was getting ready for a game

headline.main: Poor Photo

abstract: Federal court dismisses lawsuit charging that Education Department discriminated against male athletes to enforce equal opportunities for women because plaintiffs did not show that reduction in men's sports would be reversed if case was won (S)

snippet: To the Sports Editor:   I am writing in response to William C. Rhoden's "Discarding High-Heeled Sneakers" The Times, Feb. 8). Rhoden bemoans the fact that women are viewed as "trinkets and accoutrements" in male-dominated professional sports. He a...
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor: I am writing in response to William C. Rhoden's "Discarding High-Heeled Sneakers" The Times, Feb. 8). Rhoden bemoans the fact that women are viewed as "trinkets and accoutrements" in male-dominated professional sports. He also mentions Title IX, whose purpose was to make collegiate sports for women equitable to those of men.

headline.main: Equality Needed On Sports Pages
